articles.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: Donald Trump was sworn in as the 47th president and went to work signing executive orders to roll back birthright citizenship, withdraw from the World Health Organization and end federal D.E.I. programs.
articles.title: Live updates: Trump seeks to reshape American institutions with barrage of executive orders

articles.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
articles.description: Follow live updates on Donald Trump's first full day back at the White House, as his executive orders are attempting to rescind the constitutional guarantee of birthright citizenship and firing presidential appointees.
articles.title: Live updates: Trump administration ends policies limiting arrests of migrants at sensitive locations

articles.author: BERNARD CONDON
articles.description: Right-wing extremists are celebrating Elon Musk’s straight-arm gesture during a speech Monday, although his intention wasn’t totally clear and some hate watchdogs are saying not to read too much into it. One extremist group saw it as a rallying cry for their movement. Hate watchdogs said it was unclear what Musk was trying to convey and urged caution. Musk himself was dismissive of the critics who saw it as a Nazi salute, though he didn't offer further explanation. But the confusion and plea for calm hasn’t stopped critics and fans alike of the world’s richest man from reading into the gesture what they wanted.
articles.title: Musk's straight-arm gesture embraced by right-wing extremists regardless of what he meant

articles.author: TIFFANY STANLEY, GARY FIELDS
articles.description: At the inaugural prayer service, the Right Rev. Mariann Budde, the Episcopal bishop of Washington, asked President Donald Trump to have mercy on the LGBTQ+ community and undocumented migrant workers. Trump later said he “didn’t think it was a good service.” Trump and Vice President JD Vance were in attendance with their families at Washington National Cathedral, along with Speaker of the House Mike Johnson and Defense Secretary nominee Pete Hegseth. More than a dozen religious leaders spoke during the interfaith service centered on national unity. Notably absent from the speaker roster were conservative evangelicals, who are among Trump’s biggest supporters.
articles.title: At inaugural prayer service, bishop pleads for Trump to ‘have mercy’ on LGBTQ+ people and migrants

articles.author: ALANNA DURKIN RICHER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, ASHRAF KHALIL
articles.description: Former Proud Boys extremist group leader Enrique Tarrio and Oath Keepers founder Stewart Rhodes have been released from prison after their lengthy sentences for seditious conspiracy convictions in the Jan. 6, attack on the Capitol were wiped away by a sweeping order by President Trump.
articles.title: Trump pardons upend massive Jan. 6 prosecution by freeing rioters and dismissing cases

articles.author: MICHELLE L. PRICE
articles.description: President Donald Trump is spending his first full day back in the White House meeting with congressional leaders, announcing an investment in artificial intelligence infrastructure and demonstrating one of his favored expressions of power: firing people. The new president posted on his Truth social media network early Tuesday that he would fire more than 1,000 presidential appointees “who are not aligned" with his vision, including some high-profile names. Among those Trump fired: chef and humanitarian Jose Andres from the President’s Council on Sports, Fitness and Nutrition. Trump press secretary Karoline Leavitt said the president's infrastructure announcement will send a message to the world.
articles.title: Trump's first full day back in White House includes firings and an infrastructure announcement
